properties.description: "The towering bronze sculptures of Confederate generals Robert E. Lee and Thomas J. 'Stonewall' Jackson, each in a public park, were draped in black by the city after an Aug. 12 rally by hundreds of white supremacists erupted in violence. The demonstration drew throngs of counterprotesters, and one of them, Heather Heyer, 32, was killed in the mayhem." - The Washington Post ("Charlottesville judge orders shrouds removed from Confederate statues"). As of August 2018, these monuments are still in place. Recent attempts to obtain anniversary event permits at the park have either been denied or rescinded, but another rally from the same group ("Unite the Right") is planning an event in Washington D.C. in August 2018.

Just 70 miles away in Richmond, the capital of Virginia and the former capital of the Confederacy, citizens and government officials are grappling with their own set of Confederate monuments. Many of these monuments have a dedicated historic road called Monument Avenue. The city has commissioned a study and is awaiting recommendations as of August 2018. For more information: https://abcnews.go.com/US/richmond-addressing-debate-confederate-monuments-year-charlottesville/story?id=57009869

Since the tragedy in Charlottesville, there have been cities that have decided to remove these monuments from their public locations. One of the largest cities to do so was New Orleans. The city has removed 4 monuments as of August 2018, and the removal of the P.G.T. Beauregard monument actually uncovered a time capsule with various newspapers, badges, souvenirs, and photos from the Civil War Era.

properties.chapter: Robert E. Lee / Dixie Highway Monument
properties.description: Some Confederate monuments don't even reside in the South - here, a monument was placed in a small town outside of Cincinnati to honor Robert E. Lee. After the 2017 clash in Charlottesville, the monument was removed. Local outrage ensued, however, and the monument had to be returned to its original location.

What happens next? Many suggestions about how to deal with confederate monuments have been made, such as providing context to the monuments while leaving them in place. Some say that monuments should be removed and perhaps placed in museums such as this one - the National Civil War Museum in Harrisburg, PA. Certainly this topic will continue to be debated by Americans across the country.
